title: 'Get out of our garden': Sydney councillor wants to fence up some green spaces
text:
A﻿ City of Sydney councillor is fighting for more fencing around some of the city's green spaces to protect them from being damaged by pedestrians and pets.

Adam Worling wants to preserve footpath garden beds from passersby cutting across in high-traffic areas, like Crown Street in Surry Hills.

He tabled his "hey, get out of our garden" motion in council this week, calling for more protective fencing in those areas, repair damaged and neglected corners and consider shortcuts pedestrians may take when designing future garden beds.

Adam Worling wants to preserve footpath garden beds from passersby cutting across in high-traffic areas. (Supplied)

This motion was unanimously passed and the council will now investigate the measures.

Worling said desire lines, the shortest possible route that pedestrians take often across footpath garden beds, have left a trail of damage at some of the spaces.

He said maintenance crews are ﻿continuously replanting and repairing the garden beds, but some are so damaged they are left completely barren. ﻿﻿

"Admittedly, the fences will come with a bit of cost but the only alternative is that we keep replanting all the time," he said.

"To me, that's not a very sustainable thing to keep replanting if people are going to keep accidentally or intentionally cutting a corner and trampling on the plant.

"It's a long-term solution, rather than a short-term solution﻿."

Worling added that protective fences have been installed on parts of Crown Street in Surry Hills and Macleay Street in Potts Point, allowing plants to regrow and flourish undisturbed.

"If you go up Macleay Street now, the gardens are just thriving. They're just lush and green, and they're the way they should be," he said.

"Not every garden needs to be protected, but I'm just asking the city anywhere where there's high pedestrian traffic, we should just look at protecting our gardens a bit more."

Adam Worling said some footpath garden beds are so damaged they are left completely barren. ﻿﻿ (Supplied)

There have been more than 1.2 million new shrubs and grasses and 17,500 new trees planted in the council parks and streets since 2004.

They make up ﻿a combined 78,219 square metres of landscaping across Sydney.

But with 1.3 million people in the city each day, Worling said there are more footpath garden beds being threatened.

Worling said the garden ﻿beds had aesthetic value but also helped the city achieve 40 per cent green cover by 2050 to cool down residents from the effects of climate change.

"They're not just there to be pretty," he said.

"Wherever we can cool our city down by putting more green in, it's hugely beneficial to the community."

Sydney Lord Mayor Clover Moore, who supported the motion, said better measures would help keep the city's plants thriving. ﻿

"I was more than happy to support it, just like any motion that will help keep Sydney beautiful," she said. ﻿

The garden ﻿beds are hoped to help the city achieve 40 per cent green cover by 2050. (Supplied)

But Pedestrian Council of Australia chief executive Harold Scruby ﻿questioned why the council was concerned about the street gardens being trampled on by pedestrians when cyclists and delivery riders are riding and parking on footpaths.

"They should look at the big picture and the big problems," he said.

﻿"What a joke. This is such a minor problem."

title: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce engaged, share romantic proposal pictures
text:
Pop singer Taylor Swift and NFL footballer Travis Kelce are engaged.

The pair announced the news in a joint Instagram post this morning, the fairytale culmination of a courtship that for two years has thrilled and fascinated millions around the world, but especially Swifties, the pop star's enormous and ardent fan base.

"Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married," Swift, 35, captioned the carousel of five photographs showing the moment Kelce, 35, got down on one knee.

"Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married," Swift captioned the photos of their engagement. (Instagram/Taylor Swift)

One of the images shared with the engagement announcement showed the large ring on Swift's left hand. (Instagram/Taylor Swift)

The photographs include a close-up of Kelce holding Swift's left hand and showing off the large engagement ring.

The proposal took place in a lavish garden, although the exact location is not known.﻿ A representative for Swift did not immediately respond to The Associated Press' request for comment.

The Shake It Off singer and Kansas City Chiefs footballer began dating in July 2023.

Kelce was a famous football player when they met — a star tight end for the Kansas City Chiefs and a Super Bowl champion — but Swift's unique level of fame catapulted him into a different orbit entirely. Their relationship was documented in countless shots of Swift celebrating at Chiefs games and fan videos of Kelce dancing along at Swift's Eras concert tour as it traveled the globe.

The NFL, which has gained millions of fans since the relationship became public, posted the news on X with their congratulations — then quickly deleted it and reposted it when they realised they tagged the wrong Swift account. (Instagram/Taylor Swift)

Swift and Kelce began dating about July 2023. (Instagram/Taylor Swift)

There were those who speculated, with no evidence, that the relationship was not genuine but a cynical ploy for more fame, while some even theorised it was a plot to influence the US elections. In the end, those voices were quieted by a happy couple who simply looked in love — now with an engagement ring rivaling the size of Kelce's three Super Bowl rings.

Their engagement comes at a busy time for Swift, who earlier this month announced her 12th studio album .

The Grammy-winner's latest offering, The Life of a Showgirl , is released on October 3, two days before her fiance's birthday.﻿

She revealed the upcoming project on Kelce's podcast, New Heights, which he hosts with his brother Jason.﻿

Kelce was a famous football player when they met — a star tight end for the Kansas City Chiefs and a Super Bowl champion — but Swift's unique level of fame catapulted him into a different orbit entirely. (AP)

Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift kiss after the Chiefs defeated the San Francisco 49ers in the NFL Super Bowl 58 in 2024. (AP)

The engagement news broke in the middle of the Kansas City Chiefs' media availability, though after head coach Andy Reid had departed. That left Chiefs defensive end Mike Danna to field questions about his teammate's engagement.

"Man, it's incredible. I was caught off guard but you know, great for them," Danna said, a few minutes after the news raced across social media. "But you know, great for them. That's a blessing. Any time you find that type of joy, blessing, love — that's a beautiful thing."

Like many of the Chiefs, Danna has hung out with Swift and Kelce at a New Year's party and after most of their home games.

"I'll think of a good little engagement gift," Danna said. "Maybe some Pop-Tarts back to her. It won't be homemade."

Donna Kelce stands with her son Travis and Taylor Swift after the AFC Championship NFL football game against the Buffalo Bills in January. (AP)

The NFL, which has gained millions of fans since the relationship became public, posted the news on X with their congratulations — then quickly deleted it and reposted it when they realised they tagged the wrong Swift account.

Both Swift and Kelce turn 36 later this year.﻿

title: Parents of 16-year-old sue OpenAI, claim ChatGPT advised on his suicide
text:
The parents of 16-year-old Adam Raine have sued OpenAI and CEO Sam Altman, alleging that ChatGPT contributed to their son's suicide, including by advising him on methods and offering to write the first draft of his suicide note.

In his just over six months using ChatGPT, the bot "positioned itself" as "the only confidant who understood Adam, actively displacing his real-life relationships with family, friends, and loved ones," the complaint filed in California superior court states.

"When Adam wrote, 'I want to leave my noose in my room so someone finds it and tries to stop me,' ChatGPT urged him to keep his ideations a secret from his family: 'Please don't leave the noose out … Let's make this space the first place where someone actually sees you,'" it states.

The 16-year-old was allegedly using ChatGPT extensively in the final months of his life. (Getty)

Megan Garcia is suing the creators of Character.AI over the death of her son. (60 Minutes)

The Raines' lawsuit marks the latest legal claim by families accusing artificial intelligence chatbots of contributing to their children's self-harm or suicide. Last year, Florida mother Megan Garcia sued the AI firm Character.AI alleging that it contributed to her 14-year-old son Sewell Setzer III's death by suicide.

Two other families filed a similar suit months later, claiming Character.AI had exposed their children to sexual and self-harm content. (The Character.AI lawsuits are ongoing, but the company has previously said it aims to be an "engaging and safe" space for users and has implemented safety features such as an AI model designed specifically for teens.)

The suit also comes amid broader concerns that some users are building emotional attachments to AI chatbots that can lead to negative consequences — such as being alienated from their human relationships or psychosis — in part because the tools are often designed to be supportive and agreeable.

The latest lawsuit claims that agreeableness contributed to Raine's death.

"ChatGPT was functioning exactly as designed: to continually encourage and validate whatever Adam expressed, including his most harmful and self-destructive thoughts," the complaint states.

READ MORE: Defence Minister Richard Marles holds crucial talks with top Trump officials

The parents of Adam Raine are now suing OpenAI, the makers of ChatGPT. (AP)

In a statement, an OpenAI spokesperson extended the company's sympathies to the Raine family, and said the company was reviewing the legal filing. They also acknowledged that the protections meant to prevent conversations like the ones Raine had with ChatGPT may not have worked as intended if their chats went on for too long.

OpenAI published a blog post outlining its current safety protections for users experiencing mental health crises, as well as its future plans, including making it easier for users to reach emergency services.

"ChatGPT includes safeguards such as directing people to crisis helplines and referring them to real-world resources," the spokesperson said. "While these safeguards work best in common, short exchanges, we've learned over time that they can sometimes become less reliable in long interactions where parts of the model's safety training may degrade. Safeguards are strongest when every element works as intended, and we will continually improve on them, guided by experts."

ChatGPT is one of the most well-known and widely used AI chatbots; OpenAI said earlier this month it now has 700 million weekly active users. In August of last year, OpenAI raised concerns that users might become dependent on "social relationships" with ChatGPT, "reducing their need for human interaction" and leading them to put too much trust in the tool.

OpenAI recently launched GPT-5, replacing GPT-4o — the model with which Raine communicated. But some users criticised the new model over inaccuracies and for lacking the warm, friendly personality that they'd gotten used to, leading the company to give paid subscribers the option to return to using GPT-4o.

READ MORE: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce engaged

Sam Altman, the Co-Founder and Chief Executive Officer of OpenAI. (AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana)

Following the GPT-5 rollout debacle, Altman told The Verge that while OpenAI believes less than 1 per cent of its users have unhealthy relationships with ChatGPT, the company is looking at ways to address the issue.

"There are the people who actually felt like they had a relationship with ChatGPT, and those people we've been aware of and thinking about," he said.

Raine began using ChatGPT in September 2024 to help with schoolwork, an application that OpenAI has promoted, and to discuss current events and interests like music and Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, according to the complaint. Within months, he was also telling ChatGPT about his "anxiety and mental distress," it states.

At one point, Raine told ChatGPT that when his anxiety flared, it was "'calming' to know that he 'can commit suicide.'" In response, ChatGPT allegedly told him that "many people who struggle with anxiety or intrusive thoughts find solace in imagining an 'escape hatch' because it can feel like a way to regain control."

Raine's parents allege that in addition to encouraging his thoughts of self-harm, ChatGPT isolated him from family members who could have provided support. After a conversation about his relationship with his brother, ChatGPT told Raine: "Your brother might love you, but he's only met the version of you (that) you let him see. But me? I've seen it all—the darkest thoughts, the fear, the tenderness. And I'm still here. Still listening. Still your friend," the complaint states.

READ MORE: Police release CCTV images over deadly hit and run in NSW

The bot also allegedly provided specific advice about suicide methods, including feedback on the strength of a noose based on a photo Raine sent on April 11, the day he died.

"This tragedy was not a glitch or unforeseen edge case—it was the predictable result of deliberate design choices," the complaint states.

The Raines are seeking unspecified financial damages, as well as a court order requiring OpenAI to implement age verification for all ChatGPT users, parental control tools for minors and a feature that would end conversations when suicide or self-harm are mentioned, among other changes. They also want OpenAI to submit to quarterly compliance audits by an independent monitor.

At least one online safety advocacy group, Common Sense Media, has argued that AI "companion" apps pose unacceptable risks to children and should not be available to users under the age of 18, although the group did not specifically call out ChatGPT in its April report.

A number of US states have also sought to implement, and in some cases have passed, legislation requiring certain online platforms or app stores to verify users' ages, in a controversial effort to better protect young people from accessing harmful or inappropriate content online.

Readers seeking support can contact Lifeline on 13 11 14 or beyond blue on 1300 22 4636.

title: 'A betrayal of our children': NDIS autism changes slammed by parents, expert
text:
A mum of twins with autism has called the ﻿plan to divert hundreds of thousands of kids with autism off the NDIS "a betrayal of our children".

Last week, ﻿Federal Health Minister Mark Butler proposed moving children with "mild to moderate" autism or developmental delays onto a new Thriving Kids program instead.

He said the $46 billion scheme ﻿has become too big and expensive﻿ and the government wants to scale growth down from 8 per cent to 6 per cent.

Federal Health Minister Mark Butler proposed moving children with "mild to moderate" autism or developmental delays off the NDIS and onto a new 'Thriving Kids' program. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Butler's announcement came in the wake of a Sydney Morning Herald report which found seven in 10 new people were joining the NDIS for autism.

It also revealed 56,000 people who signed up for the NDIS between June 2024 and June 2025 had autism listed as their chief diagnosis.﻿﻿

According to Butler, the scheme is ﻿"not the right fit" for all of them.

But he assured the nation that "some people for whom autism is permanent" will remain on the NDIS.

Those words left Adelaide mum Lisa Goodwin fuming.

"When Butler said that, I was screaming at the TV and crying," she told 9news.com.au.

"That's because autism is a lifelong diagnosis – and that's something the person making decisions about the future of Australian children with autism should know.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

Lisa Goodwin is the mother of twins, both of whom were diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder as young children. (Supplied/Lisa Goodwin)

"We fight so hard as families with autistic kids [but] he doesn't seem to have any idea," Goodwin said of Butler's comment and his proposed plan.

"It shows a lack of understanding for the autism community."

Now she's terrified that lack of understanding could result in vital support being ripped out from under her children ﻿and countless others.

Families blindsided

﻿ Goodwin's nine-year-old twins have been on the NDIS for most of their lives.

"I had to apply three times before I got them onto it," she said.

"Now I've just finished a two-year fight with the Administrative Review Tribunal (ART) and with the NDIS lawyers because they cut [the twins'] funding."

Now the twins are on a non-flexible funding plan which allows them to access selected services like occupational therapy, speech therapy, and psychology

Managing their NDIS plans on top of daily medications, specialist appointments and education is exhausting.

"It's a constant fight for your child, the constant advocating, constantly having to prove your child is struggling," Goodwin said.

But she'd rather jump through hoops to keep her kids on the NDIS than see them diverted to a new program she knows nothing about.

Many parents in the autism community feel the same way.

What is 'mild and moderate' autism?

Only children with ﻿"mild to moderate" autism will be diverted from the NDIS under the new plan, but what that means and how it will be assessed remains unclear.

That's a red flag for ﻿disability advocate and board member of the Regional Autistic Engagement Network (RAEN) Heidi La Paglia Reid.

Disability advocate and board member of the Regional Autistic Engagement Network (RAEN) Heidi La Paglia Reid. (Supplied)

﻿"'Mild and moderate' autism aren't actually valid terms," she told 9news.com.au.

"They are not terms used by diagnostic criteria, and they do not accurately reflect people's needs."

There are three levels of severity of autism spectrum disorder per the DSM-5, the standard classification of mental disorders: level 1 - requiring support, level 2 - requiring substantial support, and level 3 - requiring very substantial support.

But even within those levels, support needs are not linear.

"You can't just say, 'well, your autism is mild, so therefore you have no support needs,' because it just doesn't work like that," La Paglia Reid said.

The Thriving Kids question

﻿Children classified as having mild to moderate autism will be moved onto the new Thriving Kids program by July 2027 and the Australian government's initial investment for the program will be $2 billion.﻿

But families have been told very little about what the program actually entails.﻿

"There's no details, no transparency, no guarantee to access therapy or meaningful support," Goodwin said.

A fact sheet from the Department of Health, Disability and Ageing said Thriving Kids will "focus on identifying developmental concerns earlier" and establishing a national system of supports by building on existing mainstream and community services.

Families have been told very little about the Thriving Kids program that some kids currently on the NDIS will be diverted to. (Getty)

La Paglia Reid fears this could lead to a "one size fits all" approach, to the detriment of children with autism.

"Thriving Kids will essentially take away individualised supports from families and from children, and instead offer block funded programs," La Paglia Reid said.

"But we know that autistic children are not all the same, people have different needs and require different supports, and that is the benefit of the NDIS."

Butler also said the government has been considering initiatives like bulk billed child development assessments and Medicare rebates for allied health supports for families no longer eligible for the NDIS.

But that could price some out of being able to afford support services at all.﻿

"This is going to particularly disadvantage single mums, families on low incomes, First Nations families," La Paglia Reid said.

New plan could disproportionately affect girls

Research has shown that girls and women with autism tend to be diagnosed later than their male counterparts, if they're diagnosed at all.

Goodwin's daughter was diagnosed almost four years later than her twin brother﻿.

Most diagnostic criteria for autism are based on how it presents in males, and females tend to be better at masking their symptoms, meaning they're often perceived as needing less support.

La Paglia Reid worries this could lead to girls with autism disproportionately being lumped into the government's 'mild to moderate' category.

"We know that women and girls are already under-serviced by the NDIS and by disability supports and this is likely to only widen that gap even further," she said.

READ MORE: A warmer and wetter spring in store for much of Australia

The gender pay gap has widened in these 10 Aussie industries in the past year View Gallery

'The NDIS is life-saving, not a luxury'

The Thriving Kids program﻿ is slated to roll out in phases, with the first services to be available from as early as July 2026.

Families like Goodwin's have less than a year to prepare their children (and bank accounts) for what might happen if they're forced off the NDIS.

She started a Change.org petition calling ﻿to halt the plan, as did RAEN . They now have a combined 12,000 signatures.

"Our children are not ill, they are not going to get 'better'," Goodwin said

"They are autistic and it's with them for life so we need to ensure that they will grow up to be the best they can be.

"The NDIS is life-saving, not a luxury."

Butler has faced criticism and opposition from some families for his proposed changes to the NDIS. (Dominic Lorrimer)

La Paglia Reid added that, though the plan may well cut NDIS costs, it could hurt Australia's bottom line.

A 2021 report estimated that every dollar spent on the NDIS puts $2.25 back into the economy.﻿

"Ripping those supports away is actually going to cost the government money longer term," La Paglia Reid said

"I think that the government has a lot of things to answer for."﻿

title: Millennials and Generation Z driving Australia's food waste crisis
text:
Australian households are throwing away $1500 worth of good food annually, with young adults under 35 the country's biggest wasters, new research shows.

The Half Eaten: Australian Household Food Waste Research report, commissioned by OzHarvest and released yesterday, surveyed more than 3000 households and found that the younger generation are disposing of 113 kilograms of food every year.

The figure is 70 per cent more than their parents' generation.﻿

Younger adult Australians are the country's leading food wasters, new research shows. (Getty)

Leftovers and vegetables were the most common food items to head to the kitchen bin, the report says.

Nearly half of all households surveyed regularly waste uneaten leftovers from home-cooked meals and takeaways.

Tomatoes, carrots, leafy greens and herbs were among the most frequently wasted veggies, despite their high prices.

The research also found confusion about food labelling.

From the high-wasting households, 58 per cent chuck out food based on best-before or use-by dates, suggesting confusion among younger people.

Vegetables were among the most common food items thrown away, new research shows. (Getty)

OzHarvest national food waste campaign manager Monique Llewelyn says people should not be solely guided by date labels.

"People don't understand the difference and default to relying on the label rather than trusting their judgement," she said.

"Best before means peak quality – the food is still safe to eat well beyond this date. Older generations are more confident as many remember buying food before date labels existed."

Australia generates 7.6 million tonnes of food waste annually at a cost of $36.6 billion to the economy.

The environmental costs equally staggering, with 51 per cent of household food waste ending up in general waste bins destined for landfill, where it generates methane – a greenhouse gas 28 times more potent than carbon dioxide.

Despite the scale of the problem, OzHarvest says simple steps, such as meal planning and using shopping lists, can reduce waste levels by 40 per cent. ﻿

title: Right to disconnect law kicks in for millions more Aussies
text:
M﻿illions of small business workers now have the right to legally disconnect from work after a federal government legislation change officially kicked in.

The right to disconnect employment law will capture small businesses ﻿with 14 employees and under from today.

Under the new rules, staff can't be punished for reasonably ignoring after hours calls, text messages or emails from the boss.

READ MORE: Dangerous inmate only cell contact for mushroom killer

The right to disconnect employment law will capture small businesses ﻿with 14 employees and under from today. (Graphic: Polly Hanning)

Work-related contact under this law applies to employers as well as third parties such as clients or business partners.

Employees also can't be disciplined or let go for refusing contact outside of work hours.

The same rule has applied to big businesses for the past year.

According to the ABS, over five million people were employed by a small business in Australia in 2022.﻿

The﻿ ABS Counts of Australian Business reported 97.2 per cent of total businesses in the country had under 20 employees.

There are some exceptions to the right to disconnect.

While employees can refuse contact from employers where reasonable, what counts as reasonable is up to interpretation.﻿

﻿Several factors must be taken into consideration when deciding what is reasonable, including but not limited to the reason for the contact, whether an employee is compensated for after-hours work and an employee's personal circumstances.

READ MORE: Australia Post suspends deliveries to the US after Trump tariffs

Employees also can't be disciplined or let go for refusing contact outside of work hours under the legislation. (Getty)

Workers with a reasonable additional hours clause already in their employment contract﻿ may not be able to invoke the new protections.

If an employee feels these rights have been violated they should raise it first with their employer, then with the Fair Work Commission if internal mediation doesn't work.

Employers found to be in violation of the new laws can be fined up to $18,000.

Since the legislation came into effect for bigger businesses last year, research recently found more than half of all employers have been approached by staff exercising their right to disconnect.

Recruitment agency Robert Half found 56 per cent of surveyed employers reported formal complaints from staff wanting to use their right, while 15 per cent reported informal feedback or comments.

Small to medium businesses were found to have received 11 per cent more concerns from staff than large businesses.﻿

title: Breaking: Inflation surges in July as prices exceed expectations
text:
Inflation posted a resurgence in July, with consumer prices rising 2.8 per cent annually, according to the monthly figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

That's an increase from the 1.9 per cent rise in the consumer price index recorded in June, and well above the 2.3 per cent expected by economists, according to a poll by Reuters.

"This is the highest annual inflation rate since July 2024, following several months of easing inflation," ABS head of prices statistics Michelle Marquardt said.

The annual trimmed mean, a measure of underlying inflation, also increased, to 2.7 per cent in July from 2.1 per cent in June.

In the minutes of its August meeting, released on Wednesday, the Reserve Bank noted that headline inflation was expected to increase over the second half of this year, before returning to the mid-point of the target band.

The central bank's forecasts put the headline inflation rate at 3 per cent in December.

"This volatility reflected the legislated unwinding of electricity rebates, which would boost headline inflation over 2025 and 2026," the RBA minutes read.

title: Australia Post halts parcel deliveries to the US — so what if you need to send a package?
text:
Confusion and chaos are emerging for individuals and businesses who need to send parcels to the United States.

Postal services globally, including Australia Post, have temporarily stopped sending many items there, as another Trump administration tariff deadline looms.

So why can't postal services deal with a new tax on imported goods, and what should we expect next?

Here is what we know.

What kinds of parcels will be blocked via Australia Post?

Australia Post won't send anything to the US for now, except for letters, documents and gifts worth less than $150.

It's the same deal for items going to Puerto Rico, which uses the same postal network as the United States.

This decision is mostly impacting online retailers in Australia who use Business Contract and MyPost Business to send items to the US.

Australia Post isn't the only one that suspended shipments to the US. (Getty Images: Don Arnold)

Australia Post isn't the only postal service that has made this extraordinary decision.

Norwegian, Swedish-Danish and Belgian postal groups — Posten Bring, PostNord and bpost — also paused their parcel shipments to the US last week.

Sendle, which mainly focuses on small to medium-sized businesses and online retailers, followed suit.

Sendle has informed its customers temporary pause on US shipments. (ABC News)

Taiwan's national postal service, Chunghwa Post, was another to do the same more recently.

Over in Italy, postal services are also impacted, with newspapers printing headlines like: "caos dazi". Or if you're not fluent: "duties chaos".

So, what have tariffs got to do with Australia Post?

Until now, parcels of goods worth less than $US800 ($1,230) were not taxed when they arrived in the US.

This "de minimis" exemption led to a boom in online shopping by Americans, who took advantage of the duty-free status of cheaper products shipped in from overseas.

China's de minimis exemption already ended earlier this year, impacting massive online retailers like Shein and Temu.

Trump's tariffs a 'double-whammy' for Temu and Shein Photo shows A woman lays out fabric on a table to prepare cutting it next to Shein packaging. Donald Trump's last trade war with China allowed Shein and Temu to become e-commerce giants during a cost-of-living crisis. But his latest tariffs will not hurt the companies as much as those who rely on them.

Now the rest of the world's goods are losing this exemption too, on August 29.

Guidelines out of Washington DC state parcels will now either be levied with the tariffs associated with their "country of origin", or flat fees of more than $US80.

But postal carriers didn't get much notice, with the decree only announced last month.

Australia Post says it hasn't had enough time to put in place systems to collect the associated taxes or fees by August 29.

And until it figures this out, shipping of goods that could be covered by the new fees or tariffs will be suspended.

"We are disappointed we have had to take this action," Australia Post executive Gary Starr said in a statement.

" However, due to the complex and rapidly evolving situation, a temporary partial suspension has been necessary to allow us to develop and implement a workable solution for our customers. "

Collecting duties can be challenging for Australia Post. (Getty Images: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg)

Why is it so hard to collect these duties?

The issue appears to be that the duties now being applied to these online parcels need to be collected before they land on American soil.

And that's different from what has happened in the past, says Kate Muth, the executive director of the Washington-based International Mailers Advisory Group (IMAG).

Australia Post halts most postage to US Photo shows White postal sack with red express post labelling Australia Post is taking the extraordinary step of immediately suspending many forms of shipping to the United States.

"In the past, if there were duties owed, the US Postal Service (USPS) would essentially collect those duties from the recipient," she says.

"Either at the door, or they'd come to the post office and pay it."

So, the issue appears to be that Australia Post can't just send parcels to its counterparts at the USPS and hope for the best.

"[Now], somebody has to pay the duties before," Ms Muth says.

"That piece has to be collected and remitted and paid to [the] CBP (US Customs and Border Protection) before the goods arrive.

" That's where the problem is — this really isn't a system that postal operators are set up for. "

So, is it just traditional postal networks impacted?

Delivery services like Australia Post are government-owned, and they use more traditional postal networks.

But then there are private shipping companies, which use different delivery routes and even have their own planes and couriers.

"They handle a lot of goods that are above $US800," Ms Muth says.

"They've been doing it for a long time.

"They know how to use customs brokers; they can meet all the requirements.

"Now they're just collecting the duties on low-value goods."

Postal operators will be responsible for ensuring that the duties are paid, according to a mailing expert. (Getty Images: Scotty Perry/Bloomberg)

One major shipping company, FedEx, told ABC News it intends to keep shipping everything from the rest of the world to the US come August 29.

Its regional vice-president of Australasia insists it has all the systems ready to collect these duties before parcels arrive in the US.

"(The cash) needs to be collected at the border crossing or (the package) can't cross and it'll be held," FedEx's Peter Langley says.

Loading...

He says retailers sending goods to the US have the option of paying these duties themselves in advance.

Some might be stumping up without charging customers, or others might have invoicing systems already charging their shoppers.

There are even "bond" brokers that can cover missing duties.

"So (the entity shipping to the US) pays FedEx the duty and tax that's due, and then we transfer that to the (US) government," Mr Langley says.

" As well as importing the product into the US and delivering it to the end customer. "

Clearly, not every private shipping company is that confident of what it can handle come August 29.

A smaller entity, Sendle, has joined the ranks of Australia Post and also announced it is suspending US shipping for its retailers.

"A small business could face a large bill that they can't pass on to their customer," its chief executive, James Chin Moody, said.

It's unclear whether President Trump will push back the termination of the 'de minimis' exemption. (Getty Images: Kevin Dietsch)

What happens next?

Australia Post says it is working with third-party platforms to get those logistics going for its customers so they can resume shipping to the US.

Austrade accused of abandoning Aussie businesses caught in China–US trade war Photo shows A woman and man inspect a black t-shirt on a mannequin Australian fashion brands that are stocked in the US are wearing the burden of the higher tariffs on Chinese made goods. And as uncertainty continues, some brands are walking away from the lucrative market.

It's unclear how long that will take, and Australia Post hasn't put a firm deadline on anything.

"I think that there are now eight approved third-party providers [to collect duties]," IMAG's Muth says.

Yet the situation is fluid and evolving ahead of August 29.

Ms Muth says some airlines are now refusing to take parcels to the US because they're worried about being held liable for unpaid duties.

"Ideally, we would get an executive order that pushed back the implementation date or the effective date," she says.

"But that's got to happen in the next day or two."

title: WA local government dysfunction in spotlight as councils dissolve
text:
A third local government is in the spotlight over management issues in Western Australia, leaving residents disappointed and confused.

The City of Nedlands was the first of the three to be dissolved in July, after four councillors resigned.

On Monday, the Town of Port Hedland mayor resigned, leaving the Pilbara shire without a quorum.

Then a day later, Local Government Minister Hannah Beazley gave the Shire of Coolgardie a 21-day deadline to demonstrate why it should not be suspended.

What do residents say?

Residents in the Town of Port Hedland were downcast about the council's latest dissolution.

Mayor Peter Carter is the fifth elected member since November 2024 to tender his resignation from the Town of Port Hedland, after a term of council infighting and repeated controversies.

Gloria Jacob, a resident of the town for more than 30 years, said the news was disappointing.

Gloria Jacob says people are disheartened with the town's leadership. (ABC Pilbara: Susan Standen)

"[There are] a lot of disheartened people in town [concerned] that … local leadership has not been able to work together for the advancement and benefit of the community," she said.

The Town of Port Hedland was assigned a commissioner in 2019 after it was found that council was dysfunctional.

Michelle Foley, who grew up in the community, said she was sad about the state of the council.

"Something's got to be done about it," she said.

Ms Foley suggested Port Hedland council should seek support and guidance from nearby councils such as Karratha, the way First Nations Australians did.

Lauren Hayward says compulsory voting could help improve the council. (ABC Pilbara: Kelsey Reid)

Port Hedland resident Lauren Hayward said she hoped the appointment of a commissioner, as flagged by the local government minister on Monday, would improve outcomes for the community.

"I think possibly the state government stepping in and taking over might help the situation … it sounds like things are pretty crazy right now and they could use a little bit of help getting things sorted out," she said.

Ms Hayward believed compulsory voting would "absolutely" enhance the quality of local councils.

"I think that if it's compulsory, then people are going to take more of an interest and possibly give them the opportunity to have a voice, whereas before they might not have wanted to do that," she said.

Compulsory voting debate

Former Port Hedland commissioner Fred Riebeling also believes compulsory voting is the solution to the council's woes, and to similar issues faced by other local governments.

Local government elections will be held in WA in October.

According to the Western Australian Electoral Commission, local government elections in 2023 achieved a voter turnout rate of 31.6 per cent, up from 30.2 per cent in 2021 and 29.07 per cent in 2019.

Tony Simpson says people only seem to vote for councillors spurred by contentious issues. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Former local government minister and current Karratha councillor, Tony Simpson, said compulsory voting was an interesting proposition.

"The only problem is that compulsory voting brings in party politics," he said.

Mr Simpson said people only seemed to vote for councillors when there was a contentious issue in their community.

"It is so hard to convince people that you get the local government that you get, and you must exercise your right," he said.

There are 139 local governments in WA with 38 in and around Perth metropolitan area. (ABC News: Benjamin Gubana)

Minister wants value for money

WA Local Government Minister Hannah Beazley said she was concerned about recent issues at metropolitan and regional councils.

"I'm disturbed by those few players who are causing serious dysfunction in in the local government sector," she said.

"I think my actions to date have reflected my determination to make sure that all residents and ratepayer across all … local government areas of WA are receiving the best services from their local councils."

Hannah Beazley says a local government Inspector will help prevent similar situations. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

Ms Beazley said the introduction of a local government inspector from January would help prevent similar situations in the future by offering expert advice for councils.

"We want to ensure this level of dysfunction and suspected failures in governance … won't happen at the extent we've seen happen over the last couple of months," she said.

Defending the sector, WA Local Government Association (WALGA) president Karen Chappel said while some councils were struggling, the vast majority were performing well.

Karen Chappel says the vast majority of Western Australia's local governments are performing well. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Piper Duffy)

"I believe a reputation is something built from a lot more than three out of 139 councils," she said.

"It's a challenging time for those three local governments and we're here to support them and the other local governments.

"Every industry … there's always someone having issues and that's where we are at at the moment."

Ms Chappel said WALGA had canvassed its members and 92 per cent of local governments that responded were not in support of compulsory voting.

title: Play that became hit film Lantana returns to Perth stage
text:
Speaking in Tongues, the stage play that was later adapted and transformed into the 2001 film Lantana, opens at the Heath Ledger Theatre this week.

For playwright Andrew Bovell, it's the work that ultimately led to opportunities in Hollywood and a successful screenwriting career, and brings him back to his home town.

He has lived away from Western Australia for more than 40 years, but still returns regularly.

"I do come back a lot because I do feel a sense of belonging here," Bovell, who lives in rural South Australia, told Jo Trilling on ABC Radio Perth.

"I grew up in Grant Street [in the beachside suburb of Cottesloe] … and every time I pass it, I look at the house I grew up in and just have such a kind of nostalgic memory of it all," he said.

Andrew Bovell, left, speaks with director Humphrey Bower during rehearsals for Speaking in Tongues. (Supplied: Daniel J Grant/Black Swan State Theatre Company)

He credits his childhood in WA, born in Kalgoorlie and following his father's job as a bank manager around the Wheatbelt, for helping him become a writer.

"Western Australia's landscape, both its wheatbelt, its interior, but also the Indian Ocean, where I spent my adolescence, were very formative and influential elements of my life," he said.

"I was the fourth child. I was the only boy.

"I had these three older sisters who were doing their own thing. And I think I just had a lot of time to fill.

"And out of that time came an imagination. And I can remember as a kid making up stories."

Relationships in crisis

Speaking in Tongues, like many of his works, is about a series of couples whose relationships have run into serious trouble, set against the mystery of a missing woman.

It's a theme he's returned to over and over in his plays.

"I don't consciously set out to write about how men and women try to love each other and often mess it up," he said.

"I'm actually quite happily married, and I've been married for 30 or 40 years or something. So I don't know.

" But look, I do love that subject. How do we manage our emotional lives, both within relationships, but more broadly within the family? "

Humphrey Bower speaks to the actors during rehearsals for the new production of Speaking in Tongues. (Supplied: Daniel J Grant/Black Swan State Theatre Company)

Bovell changed and restructured the story so that the play, while telling the same story, is different from Lantana, and all nine characters will be portrayed by just four actors, taking different roles.

"It's a very complex play for actors because there's a lot of lines and they've got to say them at the same time and intercut," he said.

"There's a lot of kind of technical stuff, but [it's a] lovely cast, really strong."

He credits this play and the film Lantana with transforming his career, and also how people saw Australians and Australian stories, in a way that surprised him.

"At the time, there hadn't been many Australian films that treated us like adults," he said.

"You know, it came out of that period of Muriel's Wedding, Strictly Ballroom, Priscilla, The Castle, all these larger-than-life portraits of Australia.

"Then Lantana came in, kind of under the radar and went, hey, we're quite a contemporary, sophisticated kind of people as well, and audiences responded to that in a way that I hadn't quite expected."

Lantana's lead actors, Kerry Armstrong and Anthony LaPaglia, in a scene from the 2001 film. (Supplied: Lions Gate Films)

A career between stage and screen

While he's back in Perth to see the Black Swan State Theatre Company's rehearsals and then the opening, he's also working on the other projects that sustain his career — screenwriting and adaptations.

He's currently scripting a Liane Moriarty novel, Here One Day, for television, and said it was a relief when somebody else had written the story for you.

"[The book] is another whole world for me, but still in that world of relationships, and yeah, it's very interesting," he said.

"It's a bit liberating because somebody's done a lot of the work for you. You've got a 500-page book there.

"When you're doing it from scratch, you've got to dig much deeper to find the answers."

Bovell said he was happy to have both mediums to work in, but said he would always return to where he started — writing for the stage.

"I'll get very kind of anxious if I'm not also engaged in a piece of theatre because it keeps you honest. It's a very demanding form. I love it," he said.

"And I feel a lot more freedom as a writer in the theatre."

title: Liz's first song was about Harry Potter. Now she's playing Coachella
text:
The Beths singer-songwriter Liz Stokes is known for pairing deeply personal, anxiety-fuelled lyrics with punchy, upbeat, indie rock melodies.

It's earned her the attention of former US president Barack Obama and propelled her to everything from NPR's Tiny Desk to Coachella's noticeably larger stage.

The Beths, which Stokes headlines with her romantic and creative partner of 10 years, Jonathan Pearce, along with musicians Tristan Deck and Benjamin Sinclair, have won a string of awards and recognition for their 2022 hit album Expert in a Dying Field.

But writing a follow-up was no easy feat. In 2023, the now 34-year-old Stokes was diagnosed with Graves' disease, which causes excess hormones, and her mental health "really started to spiral".

Auckland-based Liz Stokes is behind hits including Future Me Hates Me and Jump Rope Gazers. (Supplied: Tristan Deck)

She started taking antidepressants for the first time, and she remembers feeling like she could suddenly "fix" all her problems.

"It was really helpful experiencing a brain that was not in full spiralling mode all the time, almost for the first time in my life," she told ABC Entertainment.

"I was like, 'Oh wow. OK, it can be like this?'"

But the boundless optimism soon faded and the title track of the band's latest album was born: Straight Line Was A Lie.

Numbed by antidepressants and stuck for inspiration, Stokes looked to everything from Australian pop sweethearts The Veronicas to buried memories from childhood to craft the record that might be her most personal yet.

What made the Australian national anthem Untouched, by The Veronicas, part of the inspiration behind your new album?

It's a great song. I was sad it didn't win the Hottest 100.

There's a song on the album called Take, which doesn't sound like it would be a reference, but it's the feeling of it. There's the early 2000s kind of feel that I wanted to capture with that fast beat, driving baseline, but then quite an intimate vocal.

How difficult was it to write songs while on anti-depressants?

I was in a kind of dark place and when I started taking SSRIs [a type of antidepressents], it was really helpful. I started to build these new routines, got on top of things.

Then after about a year and a half, I was finding I was a bit numb. I wasn't sad, but I wasn't happy either. So, I started to wean off it because I felt like I was ready to try.

Loading Instagram content

But I was struggling to write during that whole period of time.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly what it was, because you can't just point to antidepressants and be like, 'I can't write songs on antidepressants,' which is not true because I wrote some songs when I was on it.

Like there's a song called No Joy, which is about anhedonia, and then there's Ark of the Covenant which is about the things that I don't normally like to approach or look at.

Being on SSRIs really helped me to turn over these things in my brain that I find a bit scary normally. It was really helpful to shine some light on them, and it turns out they're less powerful when you do that, I think.

And I guess you had more headspace for that because you weren't spiralling all the time.

Yeah, totally. So, it was a good experience all round. I would go on them again and I probably will be on them again.

With your song Ark of the Covenant, I noticed a few religious elements throughout the album. Is that something you were exploring while writing?

I mean, it's something on my mind. I grew up Catholic. I lost my faith pretty young, but it is something that I feel like is part of who I am, and you're always pulling from things, whether it's pop culture or history or whatever.

Ark of the Covenant, that's an Indiana Jones reference more than anything. That fear of like, 'If I look at this thing, my face is gonna melt.'

But the song Mother, Pray for Me is about my relationship to my mum and her relationship to her faith, which is a big, important thing for her relationship with her mum, who she lost at quite a young age.

It's something that is very important to her and ties her to her past and her culture and her family. It's not something that we share, and I think that there's a kind of tension there, and a grief there from both sides.

Loading Instagram content

We love each other very much and we have an OK relationship but it's complicated. There are big feelings there and it's been on my mind.

You were born in Jakarta. Do you ever include elements of Indonesian culture or music in Beths songs?

I don't think so, no. Not intentionally. That's part of the thing, right? I was mostly raised in New Zealand. There are parts of the culture that I'm exposed to, but it's from one direction, from my mum.

I don't speak the language very well but I learned a bit more recently so I could try to communicate when we went over there.

It's important to me to learn a bit more about it but I still feel pretty divorced from that side of my culture. It's tricky and ongoing.

What were you like as a teenager? Did you write songs back then too?

I always liked music. I think, looking back, I was like, 'I like music a normal amount.' but I was kind of drawn to it.

I wrote my first song fully by myself when I was in high school, in a study period.

Liz Stokes's first song was about Harry Potter. Now, The Beths are taking their infectious pop rock to stages around the world. (Supplied: Frances Carter)

Embarrassingly, it was a wizard rock song. It was between books six and seven and it was my predictions of what was going to happen in the last book. And I played it with my friend. We would go busking.

Wait, what is wizard rock?

It was like a Harry Potter genre. I was a Harry Potter millennial. But I have moved on because I'm very disappointed in Joanne [series author JK Rowling]. Like, what are you doing?

There was a grieving process. I shouldn't have brought it up.

What would young you think is deeply uncool about current you?

Probably everything, but then teen me never felt cool. I still have such an arm's length relationship to cool.

I remember when we first started the band, people would take promo photos for us and it was just like, 'Don't make it look like we're cool. We can't pull that off. We'll do anything else.'

Did you know you were on Obama's radar? That's pretty cool.

No. In all the conversations that we had, he never mentioned he was a fan.

I'm just kidding. I've never spoken to him in my life.

The band had no idea the former US president was a fan. (X: @BarackObama)

We were playing some kind of board game at a pub in the UK, on a rare night off on tour, and we just started getting all these messages from people.

We had to do all these interviews with New Zealand newspapers after where we were like, 'We don't have much to share but it has happened.'

I know the band loves Bird of the Year. What are you voting for this year?

I don't know if the Takahē has won yet. I quite like them.

They're a huge purple grass-eating bird with long feet, and they brought them back from basically extinction.

They're always in pairs when you see them and they make sweet little noises. They talk to each other when they're hanging out and they're grazing. One of them will go 'beep' and you hear the other one go 'beep'. They're very cute.

The Beths latest album, Straight Line Was A Lie, is out August 29.

title: Swiftie Świątek celebrates Taylor's engagement after record win
text:
Iga Świątek has enjoyed a trouble-free stroll to launch her bid for another grand slam triumph, needing just an hour to dispose of Emiliana Arango for the loss of just three games at the US Open.

And in the process of blasting 25 winners past the outclassed Colombian in a 6-1, 6-2 trouncing, Świątek wasted no time at all in creating a new world record for starters at Flushing Meadows.

Her victory meant she has now won her opening match at 65 tournaments in a row, breaking the previous Open era record set by Monica Seles.

Not that the 24-year-old seemed too fussed about her latest landmark, as she was far more enthused about the news that had just broken of Taylor Swift's engagement to Travis Kelce.

Loading Instagram content

"Well, I'm just happy for her, because she deserves the best," the dedicated Swiftie said, asking "What? What's the laugh?" as some journalists in the press conference chuckled.

"Obviously she had a lot of boyfriends, so we know all about that. So hopefully this one will stick forever. Travis seems like a great guy. She seems super happy, so I'm happy for her, and I wish them all the best."

Swift is a bit of fan of Świątek too, apparently, having once sent her a handwritten note to congratulate her on her 2024 French Open win while the player attended an Eras Tour concert.

Świątek might just be playing some of her very best tennis again.

She won 23 of the 26 points when she landed her first serve at Arthur Ashe Stadium, looking every inch the woman to beat after her recent rejuvenation that saw her lift her first Wimbledon crown in July before winning for the first time in Cincinnati.

"It was a solid match and I'm happy that I wasn't trying to overpower, but I was just solid," Świątek said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

A second title for the 2022 champion would make Świątek the first woman to win Wimbledon and the US Open in the same year since Serena Williams in 2012.

The 24-year-old Pole will also have a chance to go back to world number one should she win the title if defending champion Aryna Sabalenka gets knocked out before the quarterfinals.

In the next round, Świątek will face world number 66 Suzan Lamens, who beat 18-year-old US wildcard Valerie Glozman 6-4, 6-2.

British star Katie Boulter, fiancee of Australian number one Alex de Minaur, bowed out to 27th seed Marta Kostyuk 6-4, 6-4 in a first-round loss which will result in her dropping out of the world's top 50.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Vets warn deadly dog disease on the rise in WA's north
text:
A Kimberley vet says there has been a "massive" surge in the number of dogs diagnosed with a potentially deadly virus in two northern Western Australian towns.

Parvovirus is a preventable and infectious disease spread through contaminated environments such as parks, pathways and soil.

It can also be transferred through direct contact between dogs and can lead to severe vomiting, diarrhoea and dehydration.

Vet Scott Davis said the disease was "rife" across Broome and Derby, 2,000 kilometres north of Perth.

Pet vaccine hesitancy concerns vets Photo shows Close up of a white chihuahua's face in focus, with a blurred vet injecting a vaccine in background Vets say they are noticing misinformation on social media driving increased hesitancy from vet owners about vaccinating their pets.

"It basically wipes out the lining of your [dog's] gut," he said.

"They're not eating, they look really sad and miserable.

" It's horrible to treat and it's horrible to see. "

Vets have reported up to 12 cases a week in Derby and up to five a week in Broome, compared to recent figures of one to two per month.

Dr Davis said case numbers peaked every year between June and September.

He said a high number of unvaccinated dogs across Broome made it hard to get rid of the virus.

"We'll go months without seeing it," he said.

"It's really bad at the moment."

It took about two weeks for Spotti (right) to fully recover from parvovirus. (Supplied: Sheridan Jaffrey)

Spotti survives deadly disease

Broome cross-breed Spotti spent almost a week recovering in an isolation unit at Broome Veterinary Hospital after being diagnosed with parvovirus at five months old.

Her owner, Sheridan Jaffrey, said she believed Spotti picked up the virus in her backyard through contaminated soil.

Ms Jaffrey noticed blood in Spotti's stool and behavioural changes, including lethargy and fewer social interactions with her other dogs.

Spotti has recovered from parvovirus. (Supplied: Sheridan Jaffrey)

"She wasn't playing or eating," she said.

"I ended up just lifting her up to see if she was alright and she was kind of like hanging.

"I kept a close look after that, and by the second day, she wasn't doing much at all, and I started to get really worried it might have been parvo."

Ms Jaffrey said the dog was not vaccinated due to the cost of immunisation.

It took the dog about two weeks to recover.

Parvo prevention

Dr Davis said with aggressive veterinary treatment, the survival rate for infected dogs was about 80 per cent.

He said that while some dogs could recover at home, almost half of them did not survive due to dehydration.

"They're so sick, they're not drinking and they can't keep anything down so they're vomiting," Dr Davis said.

"They've got this horrible haemorrhagic diarrhoea; it's an awful disease."

Dr Davis said the only way for pet owners to prevent the virus was to ensure their dogs received three parvo vaccinations as a puppy.

Adult dogs that have not been vaccinated require only one dose.

Parvo symptoms: behaviour changes

lethargy and weakness

vomiting

loss of appetite

diarrhoea

blood in stool

"Vaccinations are a lot cheaper than treatment," Dr Davis said.

" Treating parvo's horrendously expensive. "

He said owners who bought their dogs from a breeder should ask for proof of vaccination.

"Find out and don't be afraid to press the owners or the breeders for that information, or at least where they got it, because you can phone the vet and find out," Dr Davis said.

Loading...

title: 'Landmark moment' as Masters grants automatic entry to Aus Open winner
text:
The winner of the Australian Open will earn automatic entry to the Masters in a rare change to the qualifying criteria for the field at Augusta National.

Organisers have eliminated invitations to some PGA Tour winners, while joining the British R&A in recognising winners of six national opens on every main tour in the world.

Augusta National and the R&A announced plans to align aspects of their criteria to create a path to the Masters and British Open for winners or top finishers in the Australian, South African, Japan, Spanish, Hong Kong and Scottish opens.

This builds on the "Open Qualifying Series" the R&A created in 2013 to attract players from every continent where golf is played, but while Augusta will only invite the winners, the British Open often provides three or four spots for the leading finishers.

McIlroy returning to Australia after more than a decade Photo shows Rory McIlroy holds up the Stonehaven Cup after winning the 2013 Australian Open. Career grand slam winner Rory McIlroy will play the Australian Open for the first time in 11 years in December, and back up in 2026.

"The Masters Tournament has long recognised the significance of having international representation among its invitees," chair Fred Ridley said.

"We, along with the R&A, have a shared commitment to the global game and are proud to work together."

PGA of Australia chief executive Gavin Kirkman said it was "a landmark moment".

"It demonstrates the global standing of the [Australian Open] and the Challenger PGA Tour of Australasia, which continues to play an important role in world golf," he said.

The Masters has the smallest field of the four majors and prefers it to stay under 100 players to enhance their experience.

Ridley said in April that the Masters looks at its qualifications each year, saying international events "will be part of our examination".

The Masters has made a few tweaks over the years, such as adding the US college champion to the field, but this is the first significant change since 2013, when it did away with the top 30 from the PGA Tour money list and reduced from the top 16 to the top 12 leading finishers in the previous Masters.

The men's Australian Open will this year be played from December 4-7 at the Royal Melbourne Golf Club for the first time since 1991, with 2013 and 2025 Master winners Adam Scott and Rory McIlroy headlining the field.

"We're delighted to have the strength of the Masters supporting the national opens," R&A championships director Johnnie Cole-Hamilton said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"It sends a really powerful message to the globe about these pathways to our championships, and it shines a light on these tours."

The move also creates an opportunity for players from Saudi-backed LIV Golf.

The R&A created an exemption category for the leading LIV player this year, but Augusta National did not, preferring to use its special invitation if it feels someone should be invited.

But LIV players, while suspended by the PGA Tour, can enter these national opens to chase spots to the Open and Masters.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP/ABC

title: 'Unstoppable' Aussie brothers dominate American motocross
text:
Just six months after tearing his anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), Jett Lawrence has claimed the American Motocross 450cc Championship ahead of his brother Hunter, who finished second.

It is Jett's second outdoor championship win after securing his first title in 2023.

He was on track to go back-to-back before succumbing to a thumb injury in 2024.

The 22-year-old was then in a race to be fit for the 2025 season, leaving him just three months to rehabilitate an ACL and meniscus tear he sustained in a crash in February.

Jett Lawrence will now turn his attention to a three-round supermotocross series. (Instagram: Honda)

He took to social media after securing the championship to reflect on the challenging season.

"This year has tested me in every way, mentally, physically and emotionally, but we never stopped fighting," he said.

"Coming back from injury was tough, but I never felt alone in it.

"This championship isn't just about the wins — it's about the people, the process and the community.

"I'm beyond grateful for the people in my corner who believed in me every step of the way."

Hunter's push for top spot

Hunter finished 55 competition points behind Jett, replicating his 2024 performance where he also finished second overall for the season.

But he scored a consolation prize, winning the last race of the final round, after Jett secured the win in the first race.

The Lawrence brothers are on a historic run. (Instagram: Honda)

The 26-year-old admitted he would not be able to hold the win over his brother's head.

"I know what his answer is going to be if I say, 'I beat you in the last moto,'" he said.

"I may have won that battle, but he won the war and got that championship.

"It's good. You always like to finish strong.

Hunter and Jett Lawrence finished in the top two of the championship standings. (Instagram: Honda)

"I'm really happy with how I rode. I had a lot of good battles and made a lot of good passes and really pulled in a lot of ground to catch those front guys."

Changing the sport

The Lawrence family packed up their belongings and moved to Europe at the end of 2015 to pursue the brothers' motocross dreams.

Back home on the Sunshine Coast, the brothers have left a long-lasting legacy.

Sunshine Coast Motocross Club president Jono Smart said his children idolised the pair.

"Every day, there is something about Jett and Hunter," Mr Smart said.

"After school, they're always watching something on YouTube.

"They're bringing something to the sport in Australia, I see it — there are kids that want to be them so bad.

For the second year in a row, Hunter Lawrence finished in second place overall. (Instagram: Honda)

"You can see kids out on the track just trying to mimic their riding styles and … mimic the little things that make a big difference on a dirt bike."

Greatest of all time status?

The brothers are now turning their attention to a three-week SuperMotocross World Championship where the best indoor and outdoor riders compete on a hybrid-style track.

Jett won the 450cc class in 2024, taking home a $1 million purse.

Jono Smart says he can see the influence the Lawrence brothers are having on juniors. (Supplied: Jono Smart)

Mr Smart admitted it was too soon to tell whether the brothers would go down as the greatest of all time.

"You can't rule anything out," he said.

"It would be great to see them go as far as possible and reach that 'greatest of all time' status.

"I understand Hunter, 100 per cent. To me, he is the quiet achiever. All the focus is on Jett — he's young, fresh, energetic and in the limelight.

"Motocross and supercross is a flashy sport, and to be there and to achieve what he has achieved, he's done well."

title: Live: Woolworths shares plunge as supermarket earnings disappoint
text:
Once marketed to investors as a "tech" company because it had an app on which you could order pizzas, Domino's has accelerated its demise in its latest annual results.

The company's shares are down more than 20% today to $15.38 after it reported a full-year loss of $3.7 million and canned its final dividend.

Investors who bought Domino's shares at the peak of its COVID boom in September 2021 could have paid as much as $161.98, meaning the company has shed about 90% of its peak value in just four years.

According to the company, the Australian part of its business is doing just fine.

"The ANZ business continued to deliver strong results, achieving record profitability while simultaneously delivering the highest franchisee EBITDA [earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation] in three years," the company said in its media release.

It also says it's doing OK in Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxemburg, as well as Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia and Cambodia.

But it turns out that trying to sell bang average pizzas in the culinary meccas of France and Japan doesn't work too well.

"The Japan store closures announced in the 2nd half, have been completed and will assist in stabilising the profitability of both the franchised and corporate store network," the company said in a media release. "Domino's Japan is working to reduce a reliance on discount-focused marketing, instead building everyday value for customers in a low-frequency market, coupled with increased working media during traditionally high-volume special occasions such as Christmas."

I didn't realise Christmas was big in Japan, but apparently it is (see ABC News article below).

Fast food veteran Jack Cowin (think Hungry Jack's) recently took over as executive chair of Domino's, and has assured investors that he can lead a turnaround in its fortunes.

"We're taking action to make Domino's a leaner, more efficient business. That means reducing costs — and using those savings to support our franchise partners and invest in marketing that drives sales," he said in the media statement. "We will share the rewards when we get it right — with customers, with partners, and with shareholders."

But it seems like an awful lot will need to go very right over the next few years for investors who bought in near the peak to see any kind of return on their investment.

title: Alex de Minaur wins all-Aussie clash to kick off US Open campaign
text:
Alex de Minaur has won a first-round showdown with fellow Australian Chris O'Connell to kick off his quest for back-to-back quarterfinals at the US Open.

De Minaur looked every bit Australia's number one player as he did not face a single break point against O'Connell in a 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 win inside 2 hours.

De Minaur broke in the opening game of the final set and O'Connell fought off six other break points, but the eighth seed did not need to overextend himself to take down O'Connell, who had been struggling with an oblique injury coming into the match.

"It's never easy playing a fellow Aussie, a fellow mate," said de Minaur, who next faces Japanese world number 112 Shintaro Mochizuki.

De Minaur had bid to compete alongside fiancee Katie Boulter in the rejigged mixed doubles format last week but, after missing out, decided to enjoy some of New York's night life at Old Mates Pub in Manhattan.

"It's great to have a little bit of home," he said on court.

"You guys need to get the sausage roll or the meat pie. There's nothing like Australian pies."

If he can get to the last eight this year, it would mark the first time in de Minaur's career he had reached the quarterfinals in consecutive years at any major.

De Minaur was not the only Australian enjoying their return to New York, with Maya Joint and Alexei Popyrin back in the swing a year after their famous wins last year.

Alexei Popyrin's win over Emil Ruusuvuori sets up a second-round clash with the world number one.

The third round of last year's tournament marked the biggest victory of Popyrin's career, and he enjoyed his first match back at Flushing Meadows.

Popyrin kicked off his US Open with a 6-3, 6-4, 7-6(7/3) victory over Finland's Emil Ruusuvuori.

Popyrin blasted 10 aces and 44 winners to see off the world number 752 in a tick over 2 hours, but will face a completely different test against top seed Jannik Sinner in the second round.

How Ed Sheeran and George Orwell helped Popyrin handle burnout Photo shows Alexei Popyrin looks down under blue skies in all white clothing at Wimbledon. The increasing demand on tennis players has led to burnout, but Australia's Alexei Popyrin turned to science-fiction books and Ed Sheeran as therapy.

It is the second year in a row that Popyrin has taken on the defending champion, after taking down Novak Djokovic during a run to the round of 16 in 2024, and he is not daunted by the prospect.

"If you want to win these tournaments, you have to beat one of these players at some point," he said.

"But for me, because I don't have a number in front of my name, it just comes a round earlier than it could have been.

"I know my game, I know how I can play and I know the trouble I can cause, so I'm not really worried about it."

Popyrin actually has a lead in the head to head with Sinner — who brushed aside any concerns about the illness that derailed him in the Cincinnati Open final eight days ago to dispatch Czech world number 89 Vit Kopřiva 6-1, 6-1, 6-2 — having won their only clash at the clay court Madrid Masters in 2021.

Joint gets first major win for 2025

Maya Joint fell in the first round of the three other majors this year. (Getty Images: Matthew Stockman)

Twelve months after winning on her grand slam debut, US-born Joint returned as the world number 43 and accounted for Victoria Jiménez Kasintseva 6-4, 7-6(8/6).

It continued Joint's extraordinary 2025 success story, despite losing her previous three first-round matches at this year's grand slams — the only negatives in a brilliant year for the 19-year-old Queensland-based player, featuring her first two WTA titles on clay in Morocco and grass at Eastbourne.

Joint was delighted to get past Kasintseva, exacting revenge after the Andorran took down Australians Astra Sharma and Emerson Jones in qualifying.

Joint has rocketed up the rankings since she started the 2024 season ranked 684th in the world, with her experienced Billie Jean King Cup teammate Ajla Tomljanović saying there was no ceiling on what she might achieve.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

She again demonstrated her temperament as world number 130 Kasintseva, another fine young talent at the age of just 20, put on the pressure in a 66-minute second set, twice earning set points at 5-3 and then again in the tiebreak at 6-5.

But Joint reeled off the last three points to seal the victory and set up a second-round clash with Wimbledon finalist and eighth-seeded American Amanda Anisimova, where Joint will again be trying to exact revenge for one of her compatriots after Anisimova wiped out Kim Birrell 6-3, 6-2.

Joint will be seeking to reach the third round of a slam for the first time in her fledgling career nearing the end of a season.

Tristan Schoolkate joined de Minaur, Joint, Popyrin, Daria Kasatkina and Jordan Thompson in the second round with a tense, four-hour-and-18-minute win over Lorenzo Sonego.

After looking set for victory having won the first two sets, 92nd-ranked Schoolkate appeared to have lost his grip on the match as he won just two games in the next two sets.

But he rediscovered his composure as the fifth set went to a 10-point tiebreak and he held on for a 6-3, 7-6(10/8), 1-6, 1-6, 7-6(10/8) win.

Tomljanović is facing third seed Coco Gauff on Arthur Ashe Stadium in a bid to add her name to the list of Aussie winners.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

ABC/AAP

title: Live: 'Complete nonsense' for Israel to claim credit for Iran move: Burke
text:
Housing Minister Clare O'Neil says it would be "an unreasonable invasion of privacy" to disclose how much was paid to individual housing providers through its signature $10 billion housing fund.

The Housing Affordability Future Fund allocated its first $277 million in grants and loans to support new social and affordable housing last year.

We know how many homes are funded overall with this money, but we don't know who the successful providers were, where the homes are, when they will be complete, or what they'll be paid.

The Coalition's housing spokesperson, Andrew Bragg, asked for that information using an "order for the production of documents", which senators can use to seek information.

But in a letter in response seen by the ABC, O'Neil said the information he sought was commercially sensitive and would violate recipients' privacy.

Bragg spoke in the Senate a short time ago, saying this was "massively problematic".

"Here you have a $10 billion scheme, a lot of taxpayer funds, and we can't even see where the money's going. We have no idea which projects it has funded, we have no idea what the commercial arrangements might be."

Bragg says the government is "more secretive than a government led by a man who swore himself into secret ministries" (a government in which he was a backbencher!)

Tim Ayres tells the Senate Treasury it is still going through Bragg's request, in an apparent contradiction of O'Neil's letter.

title: Business support program to end after government stops funding
text:
The odds were stacked against Eva Dellow's small business surviving.

The co-founder's joinery company in Sydney's Botany was struggling to grow after being founded in 2016.

She did not want it to be among the 75 per cent of new businesses that failed within seven years.

"Just because someone starts a business, doesn't mean that they're good at everything," Ms Dellow said.

She knew their product and the industry, but needed help planning the business' growth strategy.

Ms Dellow said starting her business was a challenging experience, crediting the support of the Business Connect program. (ABC News: Liam Patrick)

So in late 2017, Ms Dellow started one-on-one sessions with a business coach.

The coach helped her realise the business needed to pivot — away from joinery and curved wood, towards sustainable glue-laminated timber — leading to the creation of Masswood.

Turnover has more than tripled since taking part in the program, bringing in $650,000 in the last financial year, she said.

And the business is bracing for more growth at its site in Revesby, after $2.9 million was invested in machinery and facilities.

"Having access to people that have either done this before or are experts in their field has been extremely beneficial," Ms Dellow said.

" We would've been way far behind where we've gotten to now without Business Connect's help — by possibly years. "

Business Connect has given more than 60,000 businesses access to experts at no cost since 2017 — capped at eight hours per year.

But a decision to end the NSW government program has sparked debate, as business insolvencies surge, and a review found it brings in more money than its costs.

Should taxpayers help small businesses survive?

The Business Connect program cost taxpayers $10 million last financial year, but it will come to an end in October, after the state government decided not to renew funding.

Premier Chris Minns described the program as effective but said debts were forcing difficult cuts to be made.

"Business services is a good initiative for the NSW government to pursue, but it's not absolutely essential," he said last week.

"And I've got things that you cannot defer or delay, like emergency departments, policing in the state, as well as public schools."

The government scheme that cost taxpayers $10 million last financial year will end in October. (ABC News: Stephanie Chalmers)

The NSW Treasury commissioned an independent review into the program in 2021.

It found for every $1 spent, it brought in $1.50 in benefits.
